title: Teachings and Miracles
shortSummary: Luke 6 presents Jesus teaching on the Sabbath, healing on the Sabbath, the selection of the twelve apostles, and delivering profound ethical instructions known as the Sermon on the Plain. This chapter highlights Jesus’ authority over the law, His compassion, and the call to radical love and obedience for His followers.
timeline: c. AD 27-29 - Early ministry of Jesus in Galilee

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of Man and Messiah who teaches, heals, and calls disciples, demonstrating authority over the Sabbath and revealing the principles of the kingdom of God.

keyCharacters.name: Pharisees
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who challenge Jesus on Sabbath observance and seek to accuse Him, representing opposition to His ministry.

keyCharacters.name: The Twelve Apostles
keyCharacters.description: The chosen disciples of Jesus, including Peter, James, John, and Judas Iscariot, who are appointed to carry forward His mission.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: Referenced by Jesus as an example of God’s provision and mercy when he ate the shewbread, illustrating the principle that human need can supersede ceremonial law.

definitions.definition: The seventh day of the week, a day of rest and worship commanded in the Old Testament, traditionally observed from Friday evening to Saturday evening.
The twelve loaves of bread placed in the temple as an offering, which only priests were permitted to eat, symbolizing God's covenant with Israel.
The twelve men chosen by Jesus to be His closest followers and messengers, entrusted with spreading the gospel and establishing the church.
A simple story used by Jesus to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson, often revealing truths about the kingdom of God.

outline.heading: Jesus and the Sabbath Controversies
outline.description: Jesus defends His disciples for plucking grain on the Sabbath and heals a man with a withered hand, teaching that doing good and showing mercy is lawful on the Sabbath, emphasizing His authority as Lord of the Sabbath.

outline.heading: Selection of the Twelve Apostles
outline.description: After a night of prayer, Jesus chooses twelve apostles to be His primary disciples, establishing the foundation for His church and mission.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Ministry and Multitudes
outline.description: Jesus descends to a plain where great crowds from various regions gather to hear Him and be healed, demonstrating His power and compassion.

outline.heading: The Beatitudes and Woes
outline.description: Jesus pronounces blessings on the poor, hungry, and persecuted, and woes on the rich, satisfied, and well-spoken-of, revealing the upside-down values of God’s kingdom.

outline.heading: Ethical Teachings: Love and Mercy
outline.description: Jesus commands love for enemies, generosity without expectation, mercy, and forgiveness, setting a high standard for Christian conduct that reflects God’s character.

outline.heading: Warnings and Parables on Judgment and Discernment
outline.description: Jesus teaches about spiritual blindness, hypocrisy, the importance of good fruit as evidence of true faith, and the necessity of obedience to His words, comparing the wise and foolish builders.

application: Trust in Jesus’ authority over religious rules and prioritize mercy and doing good, especially in observing the Sabbath and daily life.
Commit to prayerful dependence on God when making important decisions, following Jesus’ example before choosing His apostles.
Embrace the radical love Jesus commands by loving enemies, forgiving others, and giving generously without expecting return.
Examine your own heart and actions regularly to remove hypocrisy and build your life on the solid foundation of obedience to Christ’s teachings.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto them, That the Son of man is Lord also of the sabbath.
keyVerses.significance: This verse declares Jesus’ authority over the Sabbath, affirming His divine lordship and the priority of mercy over legalism.

keyVerses.text: And he lifted up his eyes on his disciples, and said, Blessed be ye poor: for yours is the kingdom of God.
keyVerses.significance: The opening of the Beatitudes, highlighting God’s favor toward the humble and oppressed in His kingdom.

keyVerses.text: And as ye would that men should do to you, do ye also to them likewise.
keyVerses.significance: Known as the Golden Rule, this verse encapsulates Jesus’ ethical teaching on loving others as we desire to be loved.

keyVerses.text: And why call ye me, Lord, Lord, and do not the things which I say? Whosoever cometh to me, and heareth my sayings, and doeth them, I will shew you to whom he is like: He is like a man which built an house, and digged deep, and laid the foundation on a rock: and when the flood arose, the stream beat vehemently upon that house, and could not shake it: for it was founded upon a rock.
keyVerses.significance: These verses emphasize the necessity of obedience to Jesus’ teachings as the foundation for a stable and enduring spiritual life.
